contentrichtext.text: [[Image:Olodum-drummers.jpg|right|thumbnail|Members of Olodum performing.]] '''Olodum''' is a cultural group based in the Afro Brazilian community of [[Salvador, Brazil|Salvador]], the capital city of the state of [[Bahia]], [[Brazil]]. It was founded by percussionist, [[Neguinho do Samba]].<ref name=g1>{{cite news |first=|last=|title=Morre Neguinho do Samba, fundador do Olodum |url=http://g1.globo.com/Noticias/PopArte/0,,MUL1363688-7084,00-MORRE+NEGUINHO+DO+SAMBA+FUNDADOR+DO+OLODUM.html |work=[[EFE]]|publisher=[[G1 (website)]] |date=2009-11-02 |accessdate=2009-11-28}}</ref> One of many similar groups in the city (and elsewhere in Brazil), it offers cultural activities to young people, largely centered around music; it also offers [[theatre|theatrical]] productions and other activities. Founded in 1979, its stated aims are to combat [[racism]], to encourage [[self-esteem]] and pride among Afro Brazilians, and to fight for [[civil rights]] for all marginalized groups. Olodum is widely credited with developing the music style known as [[samba reggae]] and for its active participation in ''[[Brazilian Carnival|carnaval]]'' each year. [[Neguinho do Samba]], the lead percussionist, created a mix of the traditional Brazilian [[samba]] beat with [[Merengue music|merengue]], [[Salsa music|salsa]], and [[reggae]] rhythms for the [[Carnival|Carnaval]] of 1986. This became known as [[samba reggae]]. This "[[Blocos|bloco]] afro" music is closely tied to its African roots, as seen through its percussion instruments, participatory dancing and unique rhythm.<ref>[http://africanmusic.org/artists/olodum.html/ African Music Encyclopedia]</ref> It also directly draws from many Caribbean cultures, like [[Cuba]] and [[Puerto Rico]].<ref>Behague, Gerard. "Rap, Reggae, Rock, or Samba: The Local and the Global in Brazilian Popular Music (1985-95)." Latin American Music Review 27, no. 1</ref> Olodum's performing band (or ''Banda'') has released records in its own right and has been featured on recordings by Brazilian stars such as [[Simone Bittencourt de Oliveira|Simone]] and [[Daniela Mercury]]. Olodum performed on [[Paul Simon]]'s 1990 album ''[[The Rhythm of the Saints]]'' and at the subsequent concert in Central Park, New York City on August 15, 1991. In 1995, Olodum appeared in one of the [[music video]]s for [[Michael Jackson]]'s single, "[[They Don't Care About Us]]." The music was changed slightly to fit Olodum's style of drumming. In 1996, Olodum appeared in Heavy Metal band [[Sepultura]]'s album ''[[Roots (Sepultura album)|Roots]]'' Neguinho do Samba died of [[heart failure]] on October 31, 2009, at the age of 54.<ref name=g1/> Olodom's singer and songwriter, [[Germano Meneghel]], died in June 2011.<ref name=telam> {{cite news|first=|last=|title=La misteriosa muerte del vocalista de Olodum |url=http://teleshow.infobae.com/notas/587396-Encuentran-muerto-al-vocalista-de-Olodum |work=[[TÃ©lam]] |publisher= Teleshow|date=2011-06-13|accessdate=2011-07-09}}</ref> ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://olodum.com.br/ Olodum's home page] * [http://www.narin.com/olodum/ English language website (includes discography)] [[Category:Brazilian culture]] [[Category:Brazilian musical groups]] [[Category:Percussion ensembles]] [[Category:Brazilian percussionists]] [[Category:Samba ensembles]] {{Brazil-stub}}
